elements.content: A novel 2D layered iodoplumbate, [Ni(opd)2(acn)2] n [Pb4I10] n (1), yellow-green in color, has been synthesized. The anionic [Pb4I10 2−] n layer is comparable to the hexagonal PbI2 sheet but in a lower symmetry. Although the intercalated cations contribute negligibly to the electron transition, they induce the reconstruction of the inorganic moiety, which leads to a band-gap blue shift with respect to that of PbI2.
elements.clean_text: A novel 2D layered iodoplumbate, [Ni(opd)2(acn)2] n [Pb4I10] n  (1), yellow-green in color, has been synthesized. The anionic [Pb4I10 2-] n  layer is comparable to the hexagonal PbI2 sheet but in a lower symmetry. Although the intercalated cations contribute negligibly to the electron transition, they induce the reconstruction of the inorganic moiety, which leads to a band-gap blue shift with respect to that of PbI2.

elements.content: A new iodoplumbate [Ni(opd)2(acn)2] n [Pb4I10] n has been successfully synthesized; the [Pb4I10 2−] n layer has the highest Pb:r ratio among the anionic layered iodoplumates, which represents a motif comparable to that of the hexagonal PbI2 sheet and a more condensed pattern than that in the perovskite-type layer. The intercalated cations contribute negligibly to the electron transition but induce the reconstruction of the inorganic moiety, which leads to a band-gap blue shift with respect to that of PbI2.
elements.clean_text: A new iodoplumbate [Ni(opd)2(acn)2] n [Pb4I10] n  has been successfully synthesized; the [Pb4I10 2-] n  layer has the highest Pb:r ratio among the anionic layered iodoplumates, which represents a motif comparable to that of the hexagonal PbI2 sheet and a more condensed pattern than that in the perovskite-type layer. The intercalated cations contribute negligibly to the electron transition but induce the reconstruction of the inorganic moiety, which leads to a band-gap blue shift with respect to that of PbI2.

elements.content: Layered binary PbI2 (CdI2 type), a direct wide-band-gap semiconductor, has attracted continuous interest for several decades because of its application as a photocell, X-ray and γ-ray detectors, etc. The closely related iodoplumbate can be understood as a Pb/I hybrid generated by the introduction of suitable organic molecules/ions into PbI2, which exhibits great structural diversity and a combination of the beneficial properties of both moieties. The majority of the iodoplumbates are isolated clusters, 1D chains, while the derivatives of the 2D layer and 3D framework are relatively rare. Few heterometallic layered hybrids are also reported, such as [Bi4Ag2I16 2−] n .
elements.clean_text: Layered binary PbI2 (CdI2 type), a direct wide-band-gap semiconductor, has attracted continuous interest for several decades because of its application as a photocell, X-ray and γ-ray detectors, etc. The closely related iodoplumbate can be understood as a Pb/I hybrid generated by the introduction of suitable organic molecules/ions into PbI2, which exhibits great structural diversity and a combination of the beneficial properties of both moieties. The majority of the iodoplumbates are isolated clusters, 1D chains, while the derivatives of the 2D layer and 3D framework are relatively rare. Few heterometallic layered hybrids are also reported, such as [Bi4Ag2I16 2-] n .

elements.content: Most of the layered iodoplumbates belong to the perovskite type, in which the packing motif of the vertex-sharing [PbI6] octahedra is looser than that of PbI2. Such a density decrease is because the involvement of cations requires negative charges on the inorganic moiety. On the other hand, the packing density of the Pb/I moiety usually reflects the band gap of the compound. The Pb:r ratio is an empirical parameter to indicate the packing density of the Pb/I moiety, where r is defined as r = ∑(Nμ n -I)/n, n = 1−6; Nμ n -I means the number of n-fold-coordinated I atoms per building unit. The lower and upper Pb:r limits are 0.167 and 1.5, respectively. The lower limit is calculated from the loosest example, a discrete [PbI6]4− cluster, and the upper limit, from PbI2, the most condensed example. The perovskite iodoplumbate has a Pb:r ratio between 0.333 and 0.667. A big challenge in the synthetic chemistry is how to increase such a ratio to generate more condensed structures. Here we report a novel layered iodoplumbate [Ni(opd)2(acn)2] n [Pb4I10] n (1), with the highest Pb:r ratio (0.8) among the anionic layered iodoplumates, in which the [PbI6] connection is comparable to that in hexagonal PbI2 sheet but of lower symmetry. The single-crystal structure, optical band gap, thermal stability, and electronic structure are reported.
elements.clean_text: Most of the layered iodoplumbates belong to the perovskite type, in which the packing motif of the vertex-sharing [PbI6] octahedra is looser than that of PbI2. Such a density decrease is because the involvement of cations requires negative charges on the inorganic moiety. On the other hand, the packing density of the Pb/I moiety usually reflects the band gap of the compound. The Pb:r ratio is an empirical parameter to indicate the packing density of the Pb/I moiety, where r is defined as r = ∑(Nμ n -I)/n, n = 1-6; Nμ n -I means the number of n-fold-coordinated I atoms per building unit. The lower and upper Pb:r limits are 0.167 and 1.5, respectively. The lower limit is calculated from the loosest example, a discrete [PbI6]4- cluster, and the upper limit, from PbI2, the most condensed example. The perovskite iodoplumbate has a Pb:r ratio between 0.333 and 0.667. A big challenge in the synthetic chemistry is how to increase such a ratio to generate more condensed structures. Here we report a novel layered iodoplumbate [Ni(opd)2(acn)2] n [Pb4I10] n  (1), with the highest Pb:r ratio (0.8) among the anionic layered iodoplumates, in which the [PbI6] connection is comparable to that in hexagonal PbI2 sheet but of lower symmetry. The single-crystal structure, optical band gap, thermal stability, and electronic structure are reported.

elements.content: Compound 1 (Figure ) crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/c and features a novel infinite 2D stepwise [Pb4I10 2−] n anionic layer with [Ni(opd)2(acn)2]2+ as intercalated cations (opd = o-phenylenediamine; acn = acetonitrile). Different from the vertex sharing in perovskite iodoplumbates, the [PbI6] octahedra are edge-shared in 1 (Figure ). The 2 × 2 subunit [Pb4I10]2−, which is made of four edge-shared [PbI6] octahedra, extends along the c axis in a zigzag motif via sharing of the I3−I3 edges and propagates along the b axis via the common I3−I4 and I4−I4 edges (Figures and and , Figure S7). Similar 2 × 2 subunits could be abstracted from PbI2 with a different formula: [Pb4I8]0. Two more I− anions per subunit are involved in 1 because of the occurrence of the less coordinated μt-I1 (terminal I, one-fold coordination) and μ2-I2, while the I− anions in PbI2 are all 3-fold-coordinated (μ3-I). The μt- and μ2-I atoms are responsible for the loose packing of [PbI6] octahedra (Figure ). The anionic layer in 1 also distinguishes it from that in β-(EDT-TTF-I2)2[Pb5/6◻1/6I2]3, in which the charge balance has been achieved differently via the Pb2+ defects. The formation of the stepwise anionic layers in 1 may be attributed to the cation effect because the smaller cation in [Me2HN-(CH2)2-NMe2H][Sn3I8] induces a stepwise [Sn3I8 2−] n anionic layer but with a narrower step.
elements.clean_text: Compound 1 (Figure ) crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/c and features a novel infinite 2D stepwise [Pb4I10 2-] n  anionic layer with [Ni(opd)2(acn)2]2+ as intercalated cations (opd = o-phenylenediamine; acn = acetonitrile). Different from the vertex sharing in perovskite iodoplumbates, the [PbI6] octahedra are edge-shared in 1 (Figure ). The 2 × 2 subunit [Pb4I10]2-, which is made of four edge-shared [PbI6] octahedra, extends along the c axis in a zigzag motif via sharing of the I3-I3 edges and propagates along the b axis via the common I3-I4 and I4-I4 edges (Figures  and  and , Figure S7). Similar 2 × 2 subunits could be abstracted from PbI2 with a different formula: [Pb4I8]0. Two more I- anions per subunit are involved in 1 because of the occurrence of the less coordinated μt-I1 (terminal I, one-fold coordination) and μ2-I2, while the I- anions in PbI2 are all 3-fold-coordinated (μ3-I). The μt- and μ2-I atoms are responsible for the loose packing of [PbI6] octahedra (Figure ). The anionic layer in 1 also distinguishes it from that in β-(EDT-TTF-I2)2[Pb5/6◻1/6I2]3, in which the charge balance has been achieved differently via the Pb2+ defects. The formation of the stepwise anionic layers in 1 may be attributed to the cation effect because the smaller cation in [Me2HN-(CH2)2-NMe2H][Sn3I8] induces a stepwise [Sn3I8 2-] n  anionic layer but with a narrower step.

elements.content: (010) view of 1.
Cation effect leading to symmetry breaking. Left: single hcp layer in PbI2. Right: single [Pb4I10 2−] n anionic layer in 1. The blue rhombus confines the 2 × 2 subunit.
elements.clean_text: 2  Cation effect leading to symmetry breaking. Left: single hcp layer in PbI2. Right: single [Pb4I10 2-] n  anionic layer in 1. The blue rhombus confines the 2 × 2 subunit.

elements.content: The Pb−I bonds in 1 are quite distorted in the range of 3.001(1)−3.529(9) Å, with 3.22 Å as the average (the Pb−I bond is 3.22 Å in PbI2), and the I−Pb−I angles range from 81.63° to 104.15° and from 164.56° to 172.25° for Pb1, which is coordinated with one μt-I, one μ2-I, and four μ3-I atoms, and from 84.45 to 93.67 and from 174.28° to 177.10° for Pb2, which is coordinated by one μ2-I and five μ3-I atoms (see details in the , Table S2). The angles in PbI2 are nearly 90° or 180°, in which all Pb atoms coordinate to six μ3-I atoms.
elements.clean_text: The Pb-I bonds in 1 are quite distorted in the range of 3.001(1)-3.529(9) Å, with 3.22 Å as the average (the Pb-I bond is 3.22 Å in PbI2), and the I-Pb-I angles range from 81.63° to 104.15° and from 164.56° to 172.25° for Pb1, which is coordinated with one μt-I, one μ2-I, and four μ3-I atoms, and from 84.45 to 93.67 and from 174.28° to 177.10° for Pb2, which is coordinated by one μ2-I and five μ3-I atoms (see details in the , Table S2). The angles in PbI2 are nearly 90° or 180°, in which all Pb atoms coordinate to six μ3-I atoms.

elements.content: The diffuse-reflectance spectra of 1 and PbI2 have been measured, and the band gaps have been evaluated by the extrapolation method (, Figure S1). Their optical band gaps are 2.67 and 2.34 eV, respectively (the latter is comparable to the reported 2.27 eV for PbI2 ).
elements.clean_text: The diffuse-reflectance spectra of 1 and PbI2 have been measured, and the band gaps have been evaluated by the extrapolation method (, Figure S1). Their optical band gaps are 2.67 and 2.34 eV, respectively (the latter is comparable to the reported 2.27 eV for PbI2 ).

elements.content: The linear absorption optical properties were described in terms of the imaginary part ϵ2(ω) of the dielectric function and calculated with the CASTEP code (). As shown in Figure , the onset of the transition edges of 1 and the Pb/I anionic moiety is nearly identical. Therefore, the organic complex cations have minor contributions to the electron transition, similar to that previously reported. The electronic structures of 1 and PbI2 have been calculated (Figures and ). For the sake of a clear comparison, the cations in 1 have not been considered. As shown in Figure a, PbI2 has a direct band gap, and the highest occupied crystal orbitals (HOCOs) are mainly the antibonding states of Pb 6s and I 5p (p x /p y ) at A (k = 0.0, 0.0, 0.5) and the lowest unoccupied crystal orbitals (LUCOs) are mostly Pb 6p z orbitals (, Figures S2 and S3). The HOCO antibonding interactions are along the z axis (parallel to the crystallographic c axis), and p z orbitals of LUCOs show σ interactions between neighboring layers. The maximum destabilization is at A (k = 0.0, 0.0, 0.5), while the lowest energy of the conducting band is also observed at A, which therefore indicates the direct band-gap character. Both HOCOs and LUCOs of 1 have similar components but with larger degrees of distortion (, Figures S4 and S5). The interlayer orbital interactions are slightly off the x direction (parallel to the crystallographic a axis); the flat band structures from Y (k = 0.0, 0.5, 0.0) to A (k = −0.5, 0.5, 0.0) and E (k = −0.5, 0.5, 0.5) to C (k= 0.0, 0.5, 0.5) indicate that there is only a very weak interaction along the a axis because of intercalation of the cations. So, nearly no electron transition would occur along such an axis, and the electron transition should be confined to the Pb/I layer. This may be in response to the band-gap blue shift observed between 1 and PbI2. On the other hand, the orbital distortion may affect the transition direction of the electrons and lead to an indirect band gap for 1 (Figure b). These simple correlations suggest that, although the intercalated cations between Pb/I layers contribute negligibly to the electronic transition, the template effect of the cations causes the reconstruction of the Pb/I inorganic moiety and thus leads to different properties.
elements.clean_text: The linear absorption optical properties were described in terms of the imaginary part ϵ2(ω) of the dielectric function and calculated with the CASTEP code (). As shown in Figure , the onset of the transition edges of 1 and the Pb/I anionic moiety is nearly identical. Therefore, the organic complex cations have minor contributions to the electron transition, similar to that previously reported. The electronic structures of 1 and PbI2 have been calculated (Figures  and ). For the sake of a clear comparison, the cations in 1 have not been considered. As shown in Figure a, PbI2 has a direct band gap, and the highest occupied crystal orbitals (HOCOs) are mainly the antibonding states of Pb 6s and I 5p (p x /p y ) at A (k = 0.0, 0.0, 0.5) and the lowest unoccupied crystal orbitals (LUCOs) are mostly Pb 6p z  orbitals (, Figures S2 and S3). The HOCO antibonding interactions are along the z axis (parallel to the crystallographic c axis), and p z  orbitals of LUCOs show σ interactions between neighboring layers. The maximum destabilization is at A (k = 0.0, 0.0, 0.5), while the lowest energy of the conducting band is also observed at A, which therefore indicates the direct band-gap character. Both HOCOs and LUCOs of 1 have similar components but with larger degrees of distortion (, Figures S4 and S5). The interlayer orbital interactions are slightly off the x direction (parallel to the crystallographic a axis); the flat band structures from Y (k = 0.0, 0.5, 0.0) to A (k = -0.5, 0.5, 0.0) and E (k = -0.5, 0.5, 0.5) to C (k= 0.0, 0.5, 0.5) indicate that there is only a very weak interaction along the a axis because of intercalation of the cations. So, nearly no electron transition would occur along such an axis, and the electron transition should be confined to the Pb/I layer. This may be in response to the band-gap blue shift observed between 1 and PbI2. On the other hand, the orbital distortion may affect the transition direction of the electrons and lead to an indirect band gap for 1 (Figure b). These simple correlations suggest that, although the intercalated cations between Pb/I layers contribute negligibly to the electronic transition, the template effect of the cations causes the reconstruction of the Pb/I inorganic moiety and thus leads to different properties.

elements.content: The thermal stability of 1 has been studied by thermogravimetric/differential thermal analysis (TG/DTA) on hand-picked crystals, of which the phase purity has been confirmed by the X-ray diffraction pattern (, Figure S6). As shown in Figure , 1 first loses 3.13% weight (calcd 3.37%) above 210 °C, because of the loss of CH3CN molecules, and then 8.39% weight (calcd 8.90%) above 290 °C, because of the loss of opd molecules. Finally, 1 has been completely decomposed to PbI2, which melts at 400 °C.
elements.clean_text: The thermal stability of 1 has been studied by thermogravimetric/differential thermal analysis (TG/DTA) on hand-picked crystals, of which the phase purity has been confirmed by the X-ray diffraction pattern (, Figure S6). As shown in Figure , 1 first loses 3.13% weight (calcd 3.37%) above 210 °C, because of the loss of CH3CN molecules, and then 8.39% weight (calcd 8.90%) above 290 °C, because of the loss of opd molecules. Finally, 1 has been completely decomposed to PbI2, which melts at 400 °C.

elements.content: TG/DTA curves of compound 1.

In summary, a novel type of stepwise Pb/I inorganic layer has been found in compound [Ni(opd)2(acn)2] n [Pb4I10] n with the highest Pb:r ratio (0.8) among the anionic layered iodoplumbates. The inorganic layer is more condensed than that in the perovskite type but less symmetric than the hexagonal PbI2 sheet. The linear absorption optical property calculation indicates a minor contribution of the cations to the transition edge. However, the cation template effect leads to such a novel packing motif of the [PbI6] unit. Compared with PbI2, 1 has a 0.33 eV wider band gap and less thermal stability. New layered iodometalates are expected via the choice of suitable intercalate species and a new combination of inorganic building units.
elements.clean_text: In summary, a novel type of stepwise Pb/I inorganic layer has been found in compound [Ni(opd)2(acn)2] n [Pb4I10] n  with the highest Pb:r ratio (0.8) among the anionic layered iodoplumbates. The inorganic layer is more condensed than that in the perovskite type but less symmetric than the hexagonal PbI2 sheet. The linear absorption optical property calculation indicates a minor contribution of the cations to the transition edge. However, the cation template effect leads to such a novel packing motif of the [PbI6] unit. Compared with PbI2, 1 has a 0.33 eV wider band gap and less thermal stability. New layered iodometalates are expected via the choice of suitable intercalate species and a new combination of inorganic building units.

Finally, 1 has been completely decomposed to PbI2, which melts at 400 °C.
